title: Will the US or its coalition partners declare a no-fly zone in Syria before the end of the year?
preds: It's certainly possible. A major attack on US soil would prompt President Clinton to do *something*. If there's another 9/11, or anything close to it, Russia won't be stupid enough to stand in the way. In fact, a major ISIS attack on US soil (20% chance) would force Russia's hand and make it very difficult for them to continue backing Assad. Much like Sadam Hussein was ultimately forced out by the actions of AQ, Assad seems like the next most likely dictator fall guy.
So far there is no news of increasing friction between the U.S. or its coalition partners and Russia, so I doubt that a no-fly zone will be declared over Syria today!

I'm torn between the 1 and 0. Keeping it at a 1% is saying that I don't think the chances have diminished despite passage of time and no compelling reason for this policy. But issuing a 0% is saying that this could not possibly occur in my view. I have adjusted to a 0% given the above constraints.

I'm holding my forecast at zero, and hoping I'm right. I suppose it's possible that Turkey, perhaps with western backing, will declare a no-fly zone in the wake of yesterday's events, but this would be extremely provocative. Russia was invited to Syria by the internationally recognized Syrian government. Assad is President of Syria whether anyone likes it or not. The practical meaning of a no-fly zone would be that NATO or Turkey is presuming to forbid Russia to operate over some portion of Syrian airspace. For Turkey or NATO to declare a no-fly zone over any part of Syria after the shoot-down would be a direct challenge to Russia, and Russia would probably take the dare. Such a declaration would be a reckless escalation, the principal result of which would be another aerial confrontation between Turkey and Russia, which this time the Russians would be ready for. I'm holding at zero hoping that cool heads prevail in Ankara, Washington and Brussels.

I am worried I should be raising this following the Turkey/Russia incident, but after reading through news / political reactions and considering, I'm re-iterating at 5%.  My rationale: 1)  only 5 weeks remaining, and up to now, seems like there has been very little to no serious discussion of a no-fly-zone amongst actual decision-makers (and key among them Obama and Hollande have made no supporting statements post-Paris attacks, and in fact Obama has come out opposed.  Aides reiterated today no change in strategy). 2)  Although obviously you do not want to allow Russia to infringe on an ally's airspace, if I were Obama, the last thing I would want to do is seek to escalate a stand-off with Russia quickly.  Russian soldiers may have died here, this could get serious in a hurry.   3)  The more you focus on the aspects of it that are Russia v. Turkey, less you focus on ISIS.  People at home in all these NATO countries want to see some serious action on that front, not a cold-war style stand-off with Russia.  If NATO declares a no fly zone in Syria along turkish border, what do you think Russia will do?  Double down in its support of Assad regime, put more troops in, etc.  It would calcify situation, whereas they clearly are still thinking there may be a way to slowly pry Assad from power with political pressure over time  (see article below, as well as other public quotes from the NATO leaders).  Also, if they declare a no-fly-zone and Russia violates it, what are they going to do, shoot them down?  Russia has unequivocally stated they are opposed and it violates Syrian nat'l sovereignty.  If you declare it and then let them violate it, you look weak, but if you shoot them down, then you have even more directly set up a fight over Syrian sovereignty between Assad/Russia/Iran vs. Nato/rebels. 4)  Finally, if they were planning to make a move on no fly zone front, I think they would have announced it at Obama/Hollande meetings today (or at least hinted at the possibility to test the waters).  In what would be potentially a standoff with Russia, you would want to be transparent and deliberate in your actions.  Instead, you see Obama aides telling the press no change in strategy re: no fly zone:  http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-obama-hollande-isis-20151124-story.html From LA Times: "The loss of the Russian plane also underscores Obama's concerns about instituting a so-called no-fly zone in northern Syria, which some presidential candidates have called for in criticizing Obama's strategy against Islamic State.  Going into Obama’s meeting with Hollande, aides had signaled that the president was not considering a dramatic change of course. “There is a comprehensive strategy that is being implemented by the United States and the 64 other members of our coalition," White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said Monday. Whether Turkey’s action will alter Obama’s course remains an open question.  Obama has said he would support military cooperation with Moscow if it focuses on defeating the Islamic State rather than on protecting Assad -- a message he said he personally delivered to Russian President Vladimir Putin last week in Turkey during the Group of 20 economic summit. The White House does have an interest in trying to convince the Russians of its view that the only solution to peace in Syria includes a political transition away from Assad. "

Apart from the political niceties, the implementation of a no-fly zone is very expensive. In 2013, Gen. Martin Dempsey estimated the initial cost of a no-fly zone at $500 million, and then possibly $1 billion (that's Billion, with a B) per month after that. (http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2013/07/23/204793903/no-fly-zone-in-syria-could-cost-1b-a-month-top-general-says  ) The setup costs at that time included disabling the Syrian air defense responses: interceptors, anti-aircraft guns, anti-aircraft missile batteries and the like. It is an open question whether the Russians would permit such operations now. :-) Besides the response aircraft, which are additional to the current US mission, it requires basing, logistic support, and another largely ignored cost, effective search and rescue response aircraft, i.e., helicopters and their refueling and other support logistics. "What objectives are no-fly zone and safe zone proponents seeking from this measure? Are these objectives achievable? There are two potential objectives, which are often conflated. First, a safe area for Syrians displaced from their homes by the ongoing civil war could protect civilians from attack while they remain on Syrian soil, and might thereby reduce the flow of refugees from Syria to neighboring states and to Europe. (There are already 4 million Syrian refugees in foreign countries, mainly Turkey, Lebanon, and Jordan, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.) Second, a sanctuary where Syrian rebels could train and from which they could conduct operations against the Assad regime or the Islamic State could strengthen Syrian opposition forces in the conflict. It is worth noting that United Nations approval for a safe zone is unlikely if it appeared that it could be used as a sanctuary for anti-regime forces due to Russia’s power to veto any such resolution in the Security Council."

It is highly unlikely that the U.S. or its coalition patterns will try to establish a no-fly zone in Syria. A couple of the factors that I considered: 1) While the establishment AND enforcement of a no-fly zone may have been achievable against Assad's air force, there is little chance that such a zone could be enforced against Russian planes without a major confrontation between superpowers. Given the high costs of such a confrontation, it seems unlikely that the U.S. or its coalition partners will pursue a no-fly zone.   2) The U.S. and its coalition partners have been discussing the imposition of a no-fly zone for almost four years now, yet no action has been taken. As far as I can tell, the calculus that has led the coalition to sit on the sidelines for the past couple years hasn't changed. 3) The legal case for imposing a no-fly zone is shaky, at best. Imposing a no-fly zone would clearly violate Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, so the coalition would either have to secure the approval of the Security Council or argue that it was being done is self-defence. Russia's Security Council veto pretty much eliminates the first option. And, self-defence would be hard to argue, as the primary target of a no-fly zone would be Assad and his forces, who have avoided striking at the U.S. or its coalition partners (unlike ISIS).

In order to establish a no-fly zone, US and coalition partners would need to be willing to engage Russian aircraft that enter those zones, (barring Russia officially joining the U.S.-led coalition or being able to come to some sort of arrangement with it).  U.S. & coalition military-engagement of Russian aircraft would likely quickly spiral into a regional conflict between the world powers, if not all-out-war between them.  Russia has been heavily affected by the economic sanctions that have been placed on it, NATO is growing in size and increasing its military presence in those countries which border Russia, and Russia is in a weaker place now, in terms of the number of its regional allies, than it has ever been in recent memory, making it much more difficult for Russia to affect its geopolitical goals in the world.  All of those factors have pushed the Kremlin, citizens, and Russia et. al, towards the country-wide sentiment that "Russian needs to reassert its geopolitical presence, wherever it can."  That, mixed with the  narcissism and bravado of Russia's enigmatic leader, Vladimir Putin, suggests that it would be extremely unlikely (<9%) that Russia would join the US coalition, and almost equally unlikely (>18%) that Russia would respect a U.S., or coalition-imposed, no-fly zone.  Thus, if a no-fly zone was imposed, it would almost certainly lead to some sort of aggressions between Russia and the West.  However, unclassified U.S. military documents have repeatedly asserted that Russia is the world's most-capable militaristic and geopolitical force, after the United States (see DCDC Global Strategic Trends Programme 2007 - 2036).  Nearly every military commander is aware that aggressions against Russia would be long, difficult, and costly.  Additionally, the U.S. is war-weary from our wars in the Middle East, and U.S. citizens almost certainly do not have the resolve for their country and military to engage in such a war as a war with Russia would entail, as the war would have to be fully-protracted, fully-engaged, using the entire force at the militaries disposal, in order to win. However, despite near-universal misgivings of engaging in war with Russia, the U.S. geopolitical strategy is unusually anti-Russian/anti-Soviet.  Even during periods of peace and alliance with the region, American geopolitical interests have primarily been to ensure that Russia/Soviet Union's geopolitical strength does not eclipse the United States' (for example, one of the supporting reasons why the Hiroshima and Nagasaki A-bombs were dropped was as a demonstration to the Russia, and to solidify to Russia, and the world, that America was the sole world-power emerging from WWII).  Therefore, it is not wholly unthinkable that, (despite the danger in starting a war with Russia, and, despite that war necessarily being long, difficult, and costly), America could still establish a no-fly zone in Syria, if it thought that doing so was of considerable value to U.S. geopolitical interests.  Such a no-fly zone would not only have the benefit of curtailing a Russian hegemony of force in the region, but would also give cover to Western assets on the ground in Syria (the PKK, FSA), and establish a safe-haven for refugees, something that is much-needed as Syrian refugees flood neighboring (and Western-allied) Middle Eastern and European countries. All in all, a no-fly zone in Syria by the end of the year seems extremely unlikely.  However, the chance for the U.S. to realize the dual geopolitical rewards of protecting anti-Assad fighters on the ground in Syria, as well as preventing Russian hegemony over that area, may prove to be too tempting for the U.S. to turn down.  It's difficult, though not impossible, to see how a U.S. or coalition-imposed no-fly zone in Syria could come to fruition within the time-span of the next ~10-weeks.

The first step in establishing a no fly zone is obtaining air dominance. Unlike previous exercises in Iraq and Libya, Syria still possesses a credible air defense system, as evidenced by F-22 Raptors accompanying strike packages. This is complicated by the certain intermingling of Russian and Syrian personnel. Furthermore, Russia has brought in ~50 aircraft and air defense systems, such as the S-300. These are located on the western half of Syria, and off shore. Finally, declaration of an NFZ must be in conjunction with willingness to shoot down enemy aircraft. The risk that Russian personnel will be inadvertently killed is too high for the West to accept. No deconfliction agreement has been reached either.

no way jose, unless the Pentagon/Foggy Bottom/West Wing have lost their collective marbles....then again, the US did invade Iraq. If the US did enact a no-fly zone in Syria, that would cross a Russian red line. And the US Air Force hasn't flown against a credible anti-aircraft network since the Vietnam War and hasn't flown against a credible hostile air force since 1945. and if a no-fly zone is genuinely being discussed in DC, i hope that this time around (unlike 2002/2003) people have the courage to resign publicly instead heading down the road of another fiasco.

It's way too late for this now. There are just too many problems with this, and the Obama administration is way too cautious to attempt it. The only way it might happen is if the western powers believe that it might do something to alleviate the refugee crisis, but it's hard to imagine as a practical matter how a no-fly zone might do so. And if the refugees keep coming regardless of the no-fly zone, you've still got the refugee crisis plus the possibility of a no-fly zone escalation crisis. I don't think it will happen at all, much less by December 31.

Zona zabrane letenja: protiv koga, ruskih aviona? To bi bila luda provokacija i potencijalne posledice obaranja ruskog aviona za SAD bi bile zaista zastrašujuće. U pravnom smislu samo Rusija ima 100% osnove da proglasi zonu zabrane leta, a ako bi SAD zaista proglasile zonu nad delom ili nad celom Sirijom, mogle bi biti sigurne da će se „iznenada“ pojaviti dovoljno sistema s-300, da bi to bilo izuzetno opasno. Uzgred, u tom trenutku, Rusi mogu izjaviti da su svi S-300S  u Siriji pod sirijskom komandom i sa sirijskim posadama, što bi im  omogućilo da nekažnjeno obore američke avione (kao što se to radilo ranije u Vijetnamu i Libanu). Želim da verujem da u Vašingtonu ima dovoljno razumnih ljudi koji će odbiti bilo kakav plan koji se može završiti nuklearnim ratom između Rusije i SAD.
